editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: The Relation of the manner of the taking of Shrewsbury on Saturday the 27th of February, 1644.
div.byline: By Collonel MIRRON, and Collonel BOWYER.
div.p:
SIr William Brereton being ever vigilant to take the be≈øt opportunity of times, that might ≈øtand for the advantage of the Common wealth, and at this time t ‚Ä¢ king this occa≈øion, while≈øt Prince Maurice was advanced with his Forces on the Welch ≈øide of the Rivet D ‚Ä¢ e, whither hee was marched to releeve Che≈øter that way, Sir William Breretons forces being all on the North ≈øide of the River; for the Welch ≈øide is ≈øo barr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ that there is not provi≈øions for a con≈øiderable Party that are able to defend them≈øel ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ to lye there. Che≈øter that way if he can, Sir William Brereton
was very willing to make the be≈øt u≈øe of the occa≈øion that he could.

On Tue≈øday February the 18. th 1644. Sir William Brewerton (having received In≈øtructions from the Committee of a De≈øigne which they had again≈øt Shrewsbury; and therefore de≈øired a party of his Hor≈øe and Foot to joyne with Collonel Mittons) he made no delay therein; and Collonel Bowyer, awery able gallant Souldier was de≈øigned for the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

On Wedne≈øday February 19. Sir William Brereton having drawne out Foure hundred of Che≈øhire, and Stafford≈øhire hor≈øe of tho≈øe that were with him out of his Army, and Three hundred of the Stafford≈øhire Foot, and a Company of his owne Regiment, put them under the command of Collonel Bowyer, and ≈øent them to the Committee at Wem, well armed, and fitter for pre≈øent ≈øervice, who went very cheerefully and with admirable re≈øolutions, not doubting but that the Lord (who≈øe ble≈ø≈øing they prayed for) would ≈øtand for them and protect them, and give a ble≈ø≈øing to their endeavours.

Sir William Brewerton al≈øo ≈øent divers Petars and other nece≈ø≈øaries for the ≈øtorming of Shrewsbury, to breake open the Gates or for ≈øuch other ≈øervices as they ≈øhould find occa≈øion, in which Sir William took great paines that there might be no delay in a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of ≈øo great concernment; and it was carried on with very great ≈øpeed as may appeare by the in≈øuing d ≈øcour≈øe each thing lying in order as the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe was performed, which was performed in a very ≈øhort time, to God be the pra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

On Thur≈øday February the 20. 1644. Collonel Mitton with 500 of the Shrop≈øhire forces, and Collonel Bowyer with the afore≈øaid Che≈øhir ‚Ä¢
and Stafford≈øhire forces met at W ‚Ä¢ m, there number in all were about 1200‚ñ™ and there they received In≈øtructions from the Committee for the carrying on of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in going again≈øt Shrewsbury, Collonel Mitton him≈øelfe is one of the ≈øaid Committee, a very gallant Souldier, and one that is full of valour, and Cordeall for the publique good, as appeares by all his actions, he having in all that he hath done received very little pay; yet is not any the le≈ø≈øe active in preferring the publique before his owne private intere≈øt; And the next day they were de≈øigned to march again≈øt Shrew≈øbury, the ≈øtronge≈øt Garri≈øon in Prince Maurices a≈ø≈øotiation, and not much inferiour to the ≈øtronge≈øt garri≈øon that the King hath in all England.

On Friday February the 21. th, Collonel Mitton, and Collonel Bowyer with the ≈øaid 1200 of Che≈øhire, Stafford≈øhire, and Shrop≈øhire forces, Hor≈øe and Foot marched from Wem, they marched all Friday night, ≈øuch was their courage and earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe, with their vigilancy and care, that they would loo≈øe no opportunity, notwith≈øtanding the Coldne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øea≈øor, and darkne≈ø≈øe of the night, but went on unanimou≈øly about the worke they were de≈øigned for; Collonel Mitton led on the Van, and Collonel Bowyer brought up the Reare, the Army being drawne into a formedable marching po≈øture, in which they matched all that night.

On Saturday February the 22.th 1644. They drew neere to the Enemies garri≈øon about Three or 4 of the clocke, Collonel Mitton led on the Hor≈øe, and Collonel Reynings the Foot, and ≈øo they marched up to their very Workes about foure of the clocke that morning.

About five of the clock in the Morning Collonel Mitton having pa≈ø≈øed ≈øome of his Foote in ≈øome Boates on the Severne, which runnes all along by Shrew≈øbury, toward which River the Ca≈øtle ≈øtands, which foot were commanded by Collonel Rayning a very gallant able Souldier with Carpenters and other workemen and Arti≈øts fit for that employment who went along with them in boates, and when they came to the Walls, the Carpenters ≈øawed down the Palla≈øadoes, and the Souldiers helping one another got over, and ≈ølew the Sentinels, and ≈øurprized the Souldiers in the Court of guard, and from thence went to the Magazine, and their chiefe Workes, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of them before they opened the Gates to the re≈øt of the foot, and the Governour and many of the great ones were ≈øurprized in their bedds, and when they had made all ≈øure they opened the Ca≈øtle Gate, and let in all the Hor≈øe and the re≈øt of the Foot, and marching up with Couragious re≈øolution to enter, the Enemy within being exceedingly amazed fled, ≈øome threw downe their Armes; and all crying out Arme, Arme, which opportunity our men tooke, marched in and opened the Gates, and
Hor≈øe and foot all entred, and with the ≈øpilling of very little bloud gained the Towne.

When they had made entrance thorough the gate, and guarded the Town, our men ≈øome went into one ≈øtreet, and ≈øome into another, to ≈øearch for the chiefe Officers, and Souldiers, and great care was taken to get betweene them and the Ca≈øtle, whic ‚Ä¢ ≈øtands neere the we≈øt gate, and they took the Governour, and divers other very con≈øiderable men, be≈øides other purcha≈øe as you may ≈øee in the Li≈øt which followes.

And the Committee of Wem comming along with them, they took great care that tho≈øe who are wellaffected in the Town might not ≈øuffer, and therefore the Officers kept off the Souldiers from plundering of the Town, that ≈øo the Committee might ≈øee right done and none but Malignants onely to ≈øuffer.

And cruelly have the good people been long handled by the Cavaliers in that place, that they were no little glad that Collonel Mitton hath taken it, and accordingly expre≈ø≈øed them≈øelves to the Committee.
The Committee gave notice hereof to Sir william Brewerton, certifying him what they had done, and he hath taken care for Forces to lye neere them to releeve Collonel Mitton if occa≈øion be.

The whole County are glad of th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ he well-affected part thereof, and de≈øire that Collonel Mitton may be made the Governour thereof; who is an hone≈øt Cordeall well affected man, and of true integrity.

About twelve of the clocke on the ≈øame day the Ca≈øtle was ≈øurrendred upon Condition, that the Officers and Souldiers that were in the ≈øayd Ca≈øtle ≈øhould March away with their Armes and leave the Ammunition, and Armes, in the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, and all the Officers and Souldiers in the Town behind them.
But there were many Papi≈øts and ≈øome notable Agents that fled out of the Town, and ranne away as ≈øoone as they heard that our forces had made entrance.
